note_tweet.text: It's a story about an 85-year-old hero. It's a story about a grandfather who loved his grandson and daughters more than anything. This is a story about Shlomo. On the morning of October 7th in Shlomo's house in Kibbutz Nahal Oz his wife Hana, daughters and grandson were sleeping, he was supposed to undergo surgery and they wanted to accompany him, when the terrorists entered  the Kibbutz, Shlomo decided to do something you only see in movies. Shlomo told the family members to enter the shelter, lock the door and be quiet. But he himself did not enter it. He knew that if the terrorists came and saw an elderly man sitting alone on the sofa, they would think that there was no one else at home and so it was. His nanny said they argued with him and called him to come in and he didn't agree. "Hana, hide, I'll watch over you", Shlomo sat down on the sofa, the monsters came and shot dozens of bullets at him, he just stayed sitting. They assumed that because he was sitting there, dead, alone, the apartment was empty, and they moved on and did not enter. Later, more terrorists kept coming, seeing that an elderly man was sitting dead on the sofa and did not enter. They assumed he was alone there. And thus, in this act, Shlomo saved his family. It's a story about an 85-year-old hero who with unimaginable nobility sat on a couch and waited for the angel of death. It is a story about Shlomo, who believed in life and ended his life cruelly, alone, on the couch of his home. Not armed, not in battle, just in his silence, he was full of courage and composure in the face of the monsters that came to his house. The monsters could not defeat his great love for his family. Under the sky and freedom of birds, he was buried in Kinneret.
